45.5 [95] 8 Ni-MoS2/γ-Al2O3 4-propylguaiacol autoclave 340 °C, 5 MPa C9 100 94 [96] 9 MoSx sawdust and vacuum gas oil continuous pilot-scale plant 340 °C, 8 MPa C10-C25 - 92.16 [99] 10 MoS2/C8min−15 %SA methyl palmitate autoclave 380 °C, 8 MPa C15&C16 100 96 [28] 11 MoS2 methyl palmitate autoclave 340 °C, 10 MPa C16 99 95 [100] A mini review on catalytic hydrodeoxygenation for biofuels production: catalyst, mechanism and process Hongwei Zhang Writing – original draft Funding acquisition a b Jing Zhang Writing – original draft a Yongde Ma Writing – review & editing a Zhenping Cai Writing – review & editing a Yanning Cao Writing – review & editing a Kuan Huang Writing – review & editing Investigation Funding acquisition Conceptualization a b ⁎ Lilong Jiang Writing – review & editing Investigation Conceptualization a b ⁎ a National Engineering Research Center of Chemical Fertilizer Catalyst (NERC-CFC), College of Chemical Engineering, Fuzhou University, Fuzhou, Fujian 350002, China National Engineering Research Center of Chemical Fertilizer Catalyst (NERC-CFC), College of Chemical Engineering, Fuzhou University Fuzhou Fujian 350002 China National Engineering Research Center of Chemical Fertilizer Catalyst (NERC-CFC), College of Chemical Engineering, Fuzhou University, Fuzhou, Fujian 350002, China. b Qingyuan Innovation Laboratory, Quanzhou, Fujian 362801, China Qingyuan Innovation Laboratory Quanzhou Fujian 362801 China Qingyuan Innovation Laboratory, Quanzhou, Fujian 362801, China. ⁎ Corresponding authors at: National Engineering Research Center of Chemical Fertilizer Catalyst (NERC-CFC), College of Chemical Engineering, Fuzhou University, Fuzhou, Fujian 350002, China. National Engineering Research Center of Chemical Fertilizer Catalyst (NERC-CFC), College of Chemical Engineering, Fuzhou University Fuzhou Fujian 350002 China As the effects of environmental problems and energy crises become apparent, zero carbon routes are vital to achieve large-scale production of fuels, such as efficient utilization of biomass to produce biofuels. This critical review provides a systematic summary and guidance on the catalytic conversion of waste biolipids and lignocellulose into biofuels via hydro-conversion in respect of metal catalysts and reaction mechanisms. First, five typical metal catalysts are reviewed, including reducible metal oxides, metal sulfides, metal phosphides, metal carbides, and metal nitrides. Among them, reducible metal oxides and metal sulfides are widely reported due to their efficient hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) activity. The design and preparation of catalysts from noble and non-noble metals, especially the rational design of catalyst active sites, are explored. For metal sulfides, novel in situ synthesis methods are summarized, especially in HDO reactions using oil-soluble precursors, such as ionic liquids with highly designable moieties. The importance of support is then discussed, particularly the positive effects of morphology, synergistic metal-support interactions, and surface acidity on HDO performance. Subsequently, the reaction mechanism of biomass hydrogenation treatment to produce biofuels was explored in detail using methyl palmitate as a biolipid model compound and cellobiose as cellulose and hemicellulose model compound. We also introduce two typical processes for hydro-conversion of biomass to biofuels involving three general units: pre-treatment unit, HDO unit, and separation unit. Finally, this review provides a summary and insights into catalyst design, one-pot isomerization, operando characterization, and reaction process development. Graphical Abstract Keywords Hydrodeoxygenation Biofuels Biomass Biolipids Mechanism Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction With the depletion of fossil fuels, severe environmental issues, and increasing demand for energy (expected to grow by 28 % by 2040), the search for renewable energy sources has attracted increasing attention [1–3]. Among them, biomass is a great alternative and more competitive because of zero carbon footprint, as its energy essentially from the photosynthesis of green plants [4,5]. It is pivotal to thoroughly study the transformation of biomass to biofuels to deal with environmental issues and energy shortages [6]. Food waste (containing 22–36 % lipids) is expected to reach 2.5 billion tons by 2025, while the global production of brown/yellow grease (containing 40–84 % lipids) is around 29 million tons mainly from waste cooking oil in biorefineries [7,8]. Meanwhile, non-edible lignocellulose is the main component of agricultural waste and forestry residue. There is approximately 140 Gt of global annual production contributed mainly from agricultural waste and forestry residue with the top two substances of cereal crops and sugarcane [9]. Therefore, this review focuses on two abundant biomass sources: waste biolipids and lignocellulose. For biofuels from biolipids, two approaches have been proposed: transesterification and hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) [10,11]. While for biofuels from lignocellulose, three principal methodologies are generated: gasification combined with Fischer-Tropsch (F-T) synthesis; pyrolysis or liquefaction; C-C coupling and/or HDO [12]. A comprehensive review was provided by Bao’s team for the latest progress on F-T synthesis [13]. Zhou’s group presented an in-depth discussion on pyrolysis and liquefaction [14]. The hydrodeoxygenation of vegetable oils and animal fats was reviewed by Chen’s group focusing on effects of support, promoters, and metal-support interaction on HDO activity [15]. Recently, Zhang’s group deeply reviewed the biofuels from catalytic transformation of lignocellulose via C-C coupling and/or HDO focusing on the formulation of biofuels, such as C5–C6 paraffins, aromatic and cycloalkane liquid biofuels [12]. In addition, the HDO of lignin-derived phenolics has been comprehensively analyzed by Chen’s group in respect of catalyst types, solvents, reaction conditions and mechanism [16]. Furthermore, the more challenging HDO of lignin-derived bio-oil and raw lignin was also summarized, featuring much lower biofuel yields due to high instability and complexity of the substrate. To avoid repetition, this review focuses on metal catalysts and reaction mechanisms to understand the HDO of both biolipids and lignocellulose. First, biolipid waste, including animal fats and vegetable oils, microbial oils, waste oils, etc., were processed through transesterification with short-chain alcohols [10]. Methanol is preferred due to its high activity, low cost and easy separation. Biofuels obtained via this process are named first-generation biofuels ( Fig. 1) [17]. This transesterification technology is relatively mature and has been applied worldwide in industry. There are mainly four different production methods: homogeneous acid-base catalysis, heterogeneous acid-base catalysis, enzyme catalysis, and supercritical method [18,19]. Each of these four methods has merits and demerits. First, the homogeneous acid-base catalysis performed with great activity, but shortcomings are obvious: difficulty in catalyst-product separation, environmental pollution in large-scale production, and serious equipment corrosion. Heterogeneous catalysis can avoid these problems but requires a relatively high reaction temperature and exhibits a relatively low catalytic rate. Enzyme catalysis is considered environmentally benign. Nevertheless, the activity is highly sensitive to the alcohol solvent used, because short-chain alcohol can easily poison the enzyme. No pretreatment is required for supercritical processes due to high reaction rate and low E-factor; the output is relatively low and harsh supercritical reaction conditions and high-quality manufacture equipment are required. Although there are many advantages for first-generation biofuels such as renewable, environmentally friendly, high-octane number, but shortcomings are also obvious, such as high viscosity (especially at low temperatures), high oxygen content, poor stability to oxidation and/or condensation in air, and low calorific values. Thus, the first-generation biofuels can only be used as additives for fossil fuels [19]. Due to the high oxygen content and multiple unsaturated carbon bonds in biomass, it has raised increasing attention for the transformation of waste biolipids to biofuels via hydrogenation process, which is named second-generation biofuels (Fig. 1) [11]. The obtained biofuels have properties similar to traditional fossil fuels [20]. Typically, the hydrogenation process is carried out at high temperature and high hydrogen pressure over heterogeneous catalysts to convert waste biolipids to alkanes through a deep hydrogenation reaction [21,22]. Three reaction types are mainly involved: hydrodeoxygenation (HDO), decarboxylation (DCO2), and decarbonylation (DCO) to release oxygen as H2O, CO2, and CO, respectively [23]. Among these reaction types, HDO was preferred because of the highest utilization of carbon atoms. In addition, there are short-carbon-chain by-products in alkane cracking reactions, which reduce carbon utilization and lower the practicality of the produced biofuels. To obtain higher octane number and calorific values, isomerization reaction is performed to enhance the generation of branched alkanes and to improve low-temperature viscosity [24,25]. Compared with first-generation biofuels, second-generation biofuels show great advantages, such as environmentally benign, high-octane number, great viscosity at low temperature, low oxygen content, remarkable stability, and high calorific values. Heterogeneous catalysts in this hydrogenation process have been extended from noble metals (Pd, Ru, and Pt) to non-noble metals (Co, Mo, and Ni) [26]. Strong metal-support interactions have been comprehensively investigated on materials such as carbons, zeolites, and metal oxides, to obtain efficient catalysts with great stability [22,27]. If the catalyst has appropriate acidity, it can achieve a dual function of hydrogenation and isomerization at the same time [28]. Lignocellulose is another promising biomass due to its inedible nature and abundant output, consisting of cellulose (38–50 %), hemicellulose (23–32 %), and lignin (15–25 %) (Fig. 1) [6,29]. Through heterogeneous catalytic methods such as pyrolysis and depolymerization, lignin can be converted into aromatic compound monomers (such as phenol) [30]. Meanwhile, through acid-catalyzed hydrolysis, cellulose and hemicellulose can be transformed into furan compounds [31,32]. Subsequently, the HDO process is efficient to obtain hydrocarbon biofuels [33,34]. In the HDO of furan derivatives over palladium-based catalysts, alkane yields of up to 93 % were reported. Up to 100 % conversion of phenolics, such as guaiacol, to cycloalkanes in HDO reactions were reported over Ni-, Co-, Cu- or Fe-based catalysts under optimized reaction conditions [35–37]. In addition, direct conversion of raw biomass has been investigated. Sels et al. reported that cellulose can be majorly converted to C6 and C5 via an one-pot biphasic approach using H4SiW12O40 and Ru/C as catalysts [38]. Moreover, Wang et al. reported the direct conversion of cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin fractions in raw wood sawdust to hexane, pentane, and alkylcyclohexanes, respectively [39]. However, the carbon chain of derivatives is too short, and the products after HDO reaction are with specific energy density insufficient to function as biofuels [40,41]. Thus, condensation and addition reactions are needed to obtain high-quality biofuels, in terms of energy density and low-temperature freezing point, especially for biomass-derived compounds, such as lactones, furans, and aromatics. The Dumesic group first reported the conversion of biomass-derived γ-valerolactone (GVL) to butene under acid conditions and the subsequent condensation into C8 biofuel using HZSM-5 zeolite as a catalyst [42]. However, the output of GVL from biomass is still a challenge because of the multiple reaction steps and complex reaction mechanism as reported by Zhang’s research [43]. Angelica lactone, obtained from the biomass-derived levulinic acid, can readily self-aggregate to dimers/trimers using K2CO3 as a homogeneous catalyst [44], or react with furfural via aldol condensation [45,46], following by HDO process to get C7–C10 alkanes with a carbon yield up to 96 %. Nevertheless, K2CO3 as a homogeneous catalyst is not easily removed by water completely, which may cause environmental pollution. In addition, it was reported by Zou et al. that biomass-derived furans can condense with cycloalkanones, especially cyclohexanone with strong electrophilic properties, under acid or base reaction conditions to high-quality biofuels [47,48]. The derived furfural can also react with acetone via aldol condensation to form furfural-acetone-furfural dimer under basic conditions [49]. After the two-steps hydro-conversion on Pt-based catalysts, C12-C13 biofuels can be obtained with an overall yield up to 76 %. Also, the starting materials may not be derived from biomass, as cyclohexanones and acetone are hardly achieved from biomass. It was reported that lignin-derived mono-aromatics can be valorized into biofuels through alkylation, such as the alkylation of m-cresol with iso-propanol to C10 over Bronsted-Lewis acidic catalysts [50], and the alkylation of phenol with benzyl acetate to C13 over strong Lewis acid catalysts [51]. To get high-quality, low-freezing-point, and high-density biofuels, the synthesis of bi/tri-cyclic, spirocyclic, and polycycloalkanes/aromatic hydrocarbons has become a research hotspot. Zhang et al. reported that through a tandem two-step process of aldol condensation over ionic liquids and HDO over Pd/C in a dual-bed reaction system, C15 and C16 polycycloalkane can be formed from cyclopentanone and cyclohexanone [52–54]. In this review, the design of various metal catalysts and their HDO performance are surveyed. They are reducible metal oxides, metal sulfides, metal phosphides, metal carbides, and metal nitrides. Then, the importance of support is explored, especially the positive effects derived from morphology, metal-support synergistic interaction, and surface acidity. Subsequently, the reaction mechanisms for complex hydro-conversion of biomass to biofuels are described using methyl palmitate as a biolipids model compound and cellobiose as a cellulose and hemicellulose model compound. Next, this review introduces two typical processes for hydro-conversion of biomass into biofuels involving three units: pre-treatment unit, HDO unit, and separation unit. Finally, conclusions and challenges are provided focusing on metal catalyst design, support effects, reaction mechanism, operando characterization, and process technology. 2 Design and synthesis of metal catalysts Great progress has been made in the design of metal catalysts for producing biofuels from biolipids, lignocellulose and their derivatives. They are generally classified into reducible metal oxides, metal sulfides, metal phosphides, metal carbides, and metal nitrides. The applied catalysts are extended from noble metal to non-noble metal, and the activity is improved by synergistic effect from second elements or second phases. The H source is broadened from H2 gas to H2-free solvents via catalytic transfer hydrogenation process. 2.1 Reducible metal oxides It is well known that the active sites of metal catalysts for hydrogenation are in a metallic state. For noble metal catalysts, the metallic species exhibit excellent activity for H2 adsorption and activation to produce hydrogen radicals [55–57]. Thus, catalysts that are based on noble metals have received much attention in the conversion of biomass into biofuels [58]. In the variation of HDO or DCO reaction medium, Chen’s group observed great activity and adjustability over Ru-based catalysts in the conversion of C18 fatty acid methyl esters to alkanes [59]. On an organic porous network, Bhaumik’s group prepared a Ru catalyst that displayed robust HDO over a wide range of vegetable oils (from C10 to C18), producing long-chain alkanes in aqueous solutions [60]. It was reported that Ru nanoparticles on porous framework show a strong metal-support interaction and high resistance to leaching, resulting in great stability. Considering the positive synergic effect, bi-noble metals catalysts were designed [61]. The groups of Tomishige and Nakagawa reported catalysts that were based on M-Re for the hydrogenation of fatty acids into corresponding alcohols [62,63]. The results indicated that Pd highly interacted with Re and contributed to the reduction and dispersion of Re species, promoting the adsorption and hydrogenolysis of carbonyl group ( Fig. 2a). Meanwhile, Saha’s group also studied the performance of M-Re catalysts for the HDO of waste cooking/vegetable oils to alkanes [64]. They reported that Pd-Re and Pt-Re promote hydrogenation to generate the corresponding alcohols, like the results of Nakagawa and Tomishige’s groups. They also observed that Rh and Ru enhance C-C cracking and DCO reaction of fatty acid while Ir significantly promotes the HDO reaction to produce alkanes. The Lewis acidity stemmed from partially reduced ReOx facilitates ReO bonding with carbonyl groups and activation of acyl C−O bond, while H2 molecules are activated to generate H radicals on nearby Ir atoms (Fig. 2b). Generally, H2 is used as H source both in lab research and industrial applications. Recently, the concept of “H2-free” has received increasing attention, and catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) is a promising and green strategy for hydrogen supply in HDO processes [65]. Wu et al. investigated HDO of palmitic acid over hydrogen donors such as methanol, ethanol, isopropanol, and formic acid. The highest yield of C15 alkanes can be up to 80 % [66]. Meanwhile, Guo et al. also reported HDO of palmitic acid using formic acid as in situ hydrogen donor and DCO2 and HDO as main reaction pathways [67]. Beside formic acid and alcohol, water can also serve as a hydrogen donor. Reina et al. reported that in an aqueous medium using Ru/C as catalyst, HDO of guaiacol can be achieved without hydrogen gas [68]. Although noble metal-based catalysts exhibit excellent catalytic activity, the high cost limits their industrial applications. To reduce costs and improve catalytic utilization, the noble-metal catalysts were modified by non-noble metals. After modification, the hydrogenation activity was enhanced, and reaction pathway adjusted. Qian et al. reported that Sn doping can significantly affect the physicochemical properties of Pt/SAPO-11 catalyst, and decarbonylation can be significantly suppressed [69]. This is due to the doping of an oxophilic metal that can tune the configuration of adsorbed carbonyl groups [70,71]. For a Pt-based catalyst, the fatty acids are adsorbed on Pt surface through C-C bond followed by a DCO step with the cleavage of C-C bond to form CO. Whereas the adsorption configuration on Pt-Sn alloy are via CO bond and the HDO step that followed cleaves the C-O bond to form H2O (Fig. 2c). Combined with the efficient alkane dehydrogenation and isomerization on Pt-Sn alloy [72,73], Sn modification endows Pt/SAPO-11 remarkable performance in the HDO of methyl palmitate. Similarly, non-noble metals (Ni, Fe, and Cu) assisted Pd-based catalysts were significantly enhanced in HDO performance in fatty acid conversion to biofuels [74,75]. Furthermore, it was reported that catalysts with no noble metals can serve as alternatives for HDO processes, especially the Fe-, Co-, Ni-, and Mo-based reducible metal catalysts [76,77]. Zhang’s group investigated Fe-Ni bimetal catalysts supported on ZrO2 for the HDO of lignin-derived phenolics [78]. The C-O bond in guaiacol can be activated because of the synergistic effect of Fe-Ni, thereby achieving complete conversion and up to 99 % yield of naphethenic hydrocarbons. Combining the HDO properties of Co catalysts and acidity of H-ZSM-22, palmitic acid can be directly converted into isoalkanes with up to 73.4 % selectivity via hydroisomerization [79]. Qian’s group reported a Mo-modified Ni-based catalyst displaying a tunable configuration of adsorbed methyl laurate, leading to controllable selectivity to either HDO or DCO reaction (Fig. 2d). The presence of Ni-Mo5 + can promote the DCO and isomerization reactions, while the combination of Ni and Mo4+ can facilitate the HDO and isomerization reactions [80]. In addition, the Ni-based catalysts (not Pd-based catalysts) can exhibit special activation of the C-O bond in furans following by hydrodeoxygenation to form alkanes [81]. Typical catalysts and their performance are summarized in Table 1. 2.2 Metal sulfides Metal sulfides, with a chemical formula of MS2 (M denotes metal elements, especially for many transition metal elements), are generally with two-dimensional layered structures connected by interlayer van der Waals interactions, represented by transition metal dichalcogenide structures [82]. It has significant H2 dissociation and hydrogenation ability. The H2 molecules can readily dissociate on the sulfur vacancies of MoS2, and the split hydrogen strongly binds to the exposed Mo atoms for subsequent hydrogenation reactions [83]. Therefore, metal sulfides, especially the MoS2-based ones, can serve as excellent hydrogenation catalysts and are widely used in petrochemical industry [84,85]. Despite CoS2, NiS2, and WS2 are poor in HDO activities, the doping of Co, Ni, or W to MoS2 can significantly enhance catalytic performance [86,87]. Taking Co as an example, the catalyst was generally named CoMoS2 or CoMoS. This enhancement suggests that synergistic effects between the transition metals play an important role. Li et al. fabricated MoS2-x catalysts using Co nanoparticles as support by a solvothermal method [88]. By an in situ interfacial redox method, Co was spontaneously reduced to metallic Co without aggregation at 225 °C. Over the catalyst, HDO of lignin derived 4-methylphenol was conducted at temperature as low as 120 °C with 97.4 % conversion and 99.6 % selectivity to toluene. In addition, Tsang et al. reported that a MoS2 catalyst decorated with isolated Co atoms on monolayer basal planes is superior to traditional CoMoS2 catalysts in HDO reaction [89]. The surface Co atoms covalently bond to sulfur vacancies, resulting in the lowering of reaction temperature for HDO of lignin-derived 4-methylphenol from typical 300 °C to 180 °C. Yoosuk et al. studied the performance of Ni- and Co-promoted MoS2 in terms of HDO of oleic acid and palmitic acid to biofuels [90]. With the introduction of Ni or Co, the dispersion of MoS2 improved and the strength of metal-S-Mo bond decreased. For the Ni-promoted MoS2 catalyst, the Ni/(Mo+Ni) atomic ratio for performance optimisation was 0.2. All the HDO, DCO, and DCO2 pathways were involved in the HDO of oleic acid and palmitic acid. Relatively high H2 pressure was beneficial to the HDO, and high temperature facilitated the DCO and DCO2 reactions. In experimental and theoretical studies, the catalytic activity of metal sulfides originates from edge sites rather than inert basal plane sites [91,92]. Wu et al. reported a novel metal insertion–disinsertion strategy for the creation of abundant edge sites in the basal planes [93]. The obtained Pt-MoS2-x catalyst displays excellent HDO activity in converting lignin model compounds to biofuels. Furthermore, Liu et al. proposed a facile H2O2 etching method, and the created acid sites and defects could stabilize Co atoms and create Co-S-Mo sites [94]. The HDO of lignin-derived p-cresol to toluene was enhanced 2.4-fold under optimized H2O2 treatment conditions. When MoS2 was supported on carbon (C) or metal oxides, there was excellent HDO activity. For example, depolymerization and HDO of poplar lignin over MoS2/C [95], and HDO of biolipids model compounds over Ni-MoS2/γ-Al2O3 [96]. A novel synthesis method, named in situ fabrication of metal sulfides, using oil-soluble precursors during reaction has aroused special interest due to the efficient activity attributable to the high dispersion of catalysts, abundant sulfur vacancies, better affinity to reagents, and minimisation of mass transfer limitations [97,98]. Wu et al. explored the in situ formation of MoSx using Mo-based oil-soluble precursors [99]. The obtained sulfur-deficient MoSx catalysts had high H2 dissociation property and efficient activity for HDO conversion of sawdust and vacuum gas oil. Recently, Jiang’s group reported an in situ fabrication of MoSx using oil-soluble ionic liquids as precursors [28,100–105]. Because of the highly designable moiety in ionic liquids, various oil-soluble molybdenum-based ionic liquids using molybdate (MoO4 2-) as anion and long-chain alkyl quaternary ammonium and imidazole as cations were designed ( Fig. 3). The MoSx with high dispersion and large amount of edge sites were obtained, which afford higher HDO activity for the transformation of methyl palmitate to C16 alkane in comparison to the one using commercially available molybdenum 2-ethylhexanoate as Mo precursor. In combination with using SAPO-11 as an acid support, the isomerization of alkanes can be achieved simultaneously [28]. Although great improvements has been achieved, there is still a lack of research in secondary metal doping and the corresponding synergy effect in in situ fabrication of metal sulfides. The HDO performance of typical metal sulfide catalysts are summarized in Table 2. 2.3 Other metallic compounds Metal phosphides are another type of excellent HDO catalysts, and they are more stable than metal sulfides which suffer sulfur loss [106]. Its catalytic performance may be even better than that of metal sulfides for HDO of model compounds [107,108]. Xu et al. studied inexpensive metal phosphides for the HDO of pyrolysis oil [109], and reported activity order of NiP/AC > CoP/AC > MoP/AC, with NiP performance and deoxygenation degree comparable to those of commercially available Ru/C catalysts. Li et al. fabricated a three-dimensional nanoflower-like Ni2P-Al2O3 catalyst derived from hydrotalcite ( Fig. 4a) [110]. The Ni2P-Al2O3 with Ni:Al atomic ratio of 7:1 showed outstanding H2 adsorption and dissociation activity. Two different Ni sites were identified based on DFT calculations: Ni3P-terminated (Ni(1)) and Ni3P2-terminated (Ni(2)). The Ni(2) sites are highly active for the cleavage of C-OH bonds in HDO reactions of phenolics and lignin oil. Bui et al. explored various SiO2 supported metal phosphides for the HDO of hemicellulose derived 2-methyltetrahydrofuran, showing an activity order of Ni2P > WP > MoP > CoP > FeP> Pd/Al2O3 [111]. Meanwhile, Oyama et al. investigated these metal phosphides for the HDO of guaiacol [108]. Upon active-site normalization (based on CO-chemisorption results), the Ni2P catalyst again presented the highest activity. The reaction pathway for HDO of guaiacol in a packed bed reactor is highly related to the contact time during reaction. At a long contact time of 20 min, the HDO of guaiacol starts with -CH3 elimination and then followed by -OH elimination, to generate phenol and benzene. While at a short contact time of 0.4 min, the direct elimination of -O-CH3 to phenol is preferred. With properties similar to those of Pt metal [112], metal carbides, such as molybdenum carbide (Mo2C), display excellent performance in HDO reactions. Compared with precious metals, metal carbides have advantages: cheaper, more stable, not subject to CO and S poisoning, and resistance to sintering. Chen et al. reviewed the properties of transition metal carbide (TMC) catalysts for the HDO of biomass-derived oxygenates, such as linear chain-, phenolic-, and furan-based oxygenates [113]. The high selectivity to cleavage of C-O and CO bonds, especially for Mo2C and WC, making them promising HDO catalysts for biofuels production. Jiao et al. fabricated orthorhombic β-Mo2C (space group Pbcn) and α-W2C (space group Pbcn) with ordered mesopores and large surface areas, which shows great activity for the HDO of anisole to benzene [114]. The selectivity to benzene for α-W2C is 96 % but only 80 % for β-Mo2C, which is attributed to the strong oxygen affinity of W atoms. Deactivation is plausibly due to carbon deficiency on the surface rather than coke deposition or oxidation of catalyst surface by water. Bitter et al. explored the effect of crystal structure of Mo2C on its performance for HDO of stearic acid [115]. With variation of carburizing conditions, α-MoC1-x and β-Mo2C were obtained (Fig. 4b). The former performed better, maybe due to its lower site density and higher reagent accessibility. Metal nitrides, especially those of transition metals, have been demonstrated to be great catalysts for HDO reaction [116]. The insertion of N atoms into metal lattice results in the hybridization of N p-orbital with transition metal d-orbital, causing an increase of states density at the fermi level like that of noble metals [117,118]. Ji et al. recently reviewed Mo and W nitrides for the HDO of lignin model compounds and real lignin, such as pine wood and kraft lignin [119]. The results show that the nitride species, supports, and metal promoters play significant roles in catalyst fabrication for robust HDO reactions. Many research groups reported the synthesis of bimetallic nitrides (such as Ni-Mo and Co-Mo nitrides), and the successful application for HDO, presenting great activity for the activation of CO bonds [120,121]. However, it is worth noting that Co3Mo3N exists as a η-carbide structure, while Ni3Mo3N does not exist and was confirmed to be a mixture of Ni metal and Ni2Mo3N with a β-Mn structure [122]. The diffraction pattern identified as PDF 049–1336 of Ni3No3N structure is unfounded. Arun et al. investigated a number of metal nitrides (i.e., MoN, VN, WN) towards oleic acid HDO to biofuels, with MoN supported on γ-Al2O3 showing the best performance [123]. Further doping MoN with Ni enhanced HDO efficiency due to the oxidation states of Mo and new coordination environment, which was evidenced by the existence of Mo-O and Mo-N via EXAFS. Furthermore, the combination of metal carbides and nitrides may present unexpected catalytic ability. Chen et al. reported the fabrication of Ni2Mo3N and Mo2C with adjustable Ni/Mo ratio [124]. The great HDO activity derived from the synergistic electron interaction among Ni, C, N, and Mo, with preferred activation of C-O bonds over Mo2C and C-C bonds over Ni2Mo3N (Fig. 4c). 3 Catalyst support The catalyst support is highly important towards the HDO reaction for biofuels production in both activity and selectivity, as it is more challenging to maintain high metal dispersion and high stability under harsh HDO reaction conditions [119]. Furthermore, the acidity and post-modification of supports is crucial for the dehydration and isomerization steps in HDO reaction [28]. Active carbon, oxides, and zeolites are common supports [63,67,76,79], but emerging materials, such as porous organic polymers and metal organic frameworks (MOF) have been reported as supports to fabricate efficient HDO catalysts [60,114,125]. Xu et al. reported the rapid deactivation of Mo/Al2O3 in comparison to Mo/C due to coke formation on the strong acidic sites of A2O3 [109]. Hensen et al. investigated the effect of supports on NiMo bimetal sulfides towards the HDO of methyl oleate, including AC, SiO2, Al2O3, and SiO2-Al2O3 [126]. The morphology (e.g., dispersion and stacking) of bimetal sulfides can be significantly influenced, with NiMo/AC showing the highest dispersion due to its large surface area and weak sulfides-support interaction. Effect of carbon pore size on HDO reactions was studied [119]. Wu et al. investigated β-Mo2C/C using three carbon supports: macro carbon with large pore size of ∼10 nm, activated carbon with abundant micropores, and graphite with smooth surface ( Fig. 5a) [127]. The Mo2C/macro carbon gave a high yield to aromatic compounds, while Mo2C/activated carbon exhibited good selectivity to aromatic hydrocarbons. The results illustrate that the selectivity and C-C or C-O cleavage are highly related to the accessibility of reagent fragments to the active sites. In addition, the macro carbon is also good for the resilience of aggregation of metal particles [128]. Due to the aggregation effect, the Mo2C on meso carbon presents a volcano trend to aromatic yield peaking at the catalyst with 10 wt% Mo loading. But no aggregation was observed for Mo2C/macro carbon catalysts with even 30 wt% Mo loading. Taking advantage of synergistic effects between metal active sites and acidic sites on the support (Fig. 5b), excellent HDO activity was achieved over Pd/NbOPO4 [129] and CoMoS/NbOPO4 [130] in the conversion of lipids into biofuels. Inspired by this positive effect, Wang et al. modified Pd/SiO2 with the grafting of heteropolyacid (HPA) on SiO2 surface to obtain Pd/HPA-SiO2 catalyst [131]. The high dispersion of Pd atoms and strong Brønsted acid sites introduced by grafted heteropolyacid facilitate the HDO of lipids to alkanes. The HDO and isomerization of lipids can occur simultaneously on zeolite supported metal catalysts to form mono-branched isomers with high octane numbers [132]. But the multi-branched isomer byproduct is significant due to the relatively high reaction temperature and strong acid sites of zeolite supports. Qian et al. proposed an overgrowth approach to passivate the external acid sites of zeolites to improve the selectivity to mono-isomers [133]. With the optimized silica shell, the Pt/ZSM-22@SiO2 catalyst exhibited a significant increase of mono-isomers selectivity from 71 % to 95 %. 4 Reaction mechanism for hydro-conversion of biomass to biofuels The reaction mechanism for catalytic conversion of biomass to biofuels is extremely complex, including HDO, DCO, DCO2, isomerization, ring-opening, cracking, and other side reactions. Herein, methyl palmitate as a biolipids model compound and cellobiose as cellulose and hemicellulose model compound are taken to elucidate the hydro-conversion mechanism of biolipids and lignocellulose to biofuels. For methyl palmitate, a reaction diagram is proposed in Fig. 6a [28,100]. It initially undergoes ester hydrogenolysis to palmitic acid and CH4 rather than hydrolysis because of the absence of water in the system. Then the palmitic acid intermediate engages in two reaction pathways. It can be partially undergoing hydrogenation and dehydration to C15H31-CHO, which further hydrogenated to C16H33-OH. The formed C16H33-OH goes through direct hydrogenolysis to n-C16H34 or dehydration to C15H30=CH2, which interconverted with n-C16H34. At the same time, isomeric hexadecane is generated through rearrangement of hexadecene carbocation. On the other hand, palmitic acid and C15H31-CHO undergo DCO or DCO2 to form C15 alkanes or alkenes. The formation of C15H31-OH from palmitic acid via DCO is not favored as the kinetic rate was closed to 0 [28]. The C14H28=CH2 intermediate interconverts with n-C15H32. Simultaneously, through the rearrangement of pentadecene carbocation, isomeric pentadecane is generated. Among the reactions, the conversion of palmitic acid to C15H31-CHO and finally to n-C16H34 via hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis is more favourable than the one in which palmitic acid undergoes DCO or DCO2 reaction to n-C15H32. In addition, the selectivity to iso-paraffins through rearrangement of alkene carbocation ions is quite high with the existence of strong acid sites. Experiments show that intermediates palmitic acid and alcohol are rapidly formed at the beginning and gradually converted to C15 and C16 biofuels as hydrogenation proceeds. For cellobiose, Wang et al. conducted the hydrogenation reaction at 170 °C using Pt/NbOPO4 as catalyst without adding water. The reaction mechanism was proposed based on the analysis of products, including water-soluble and organic-soluble compounds as displayed in Fig. 6b. [39]. Since water is absent initially, the hydrogenation and β-1,4 linkage cleavage to 2 and 6 can only take place via hydrogenolysis rather than hydrolysis. The formed 6 then goes through hydrogenation and dehydration to 8, which hydrodeoxygenates to 12, 16 and 18, and finally C6 is formed. Whereas the formed 2 can undergo three different reaction pathways to C6. (i) Start from the hydrogenolysis of 2 to 3, followed by dehydration to 4 and 5, and finally hydrogenolysis via 13, 16, and 17 to C6. (ii) Beginning with the isomerization of fructose and continuous dehydration, hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural, C6 can be obtained via 9, 11, 18 and 10, 14. (iii) Dehydration of 2 to 7 followed by hydrogenolysis for C6 formation via 15 and 16. 5 Process for hydro-conversion of biomass to biofuels Understanding the hydro-conversion process of biomass into biofuels is extremely important for industry applications, which usually includes three units: pre-treatment unit, HDO unit, and separation unit. Herein, two typical processes for converting biolipids and corn stover biomass to biofuels are discussed to illustrate the details of hydro-conversion process [134,135]. For the process of biolipids, the fixed-bed HDO technology is mainly applied in industry, such as NExBTL (Next Generation Biomass to Liquid) technology in Finland Neste Oil company, Ecofining technology in UOP and ENI companies, H-BIO technology in Petrobaras, and H-T (Haldor Topsoe) technology in Topsoe [134,136,137]. But the limitations are significant because of the high acid value and impurities (Fe, Ca, N, S, P, and so on) of waste biolipids caused ready deactivation of catalysts (generally, the ones based on Ni-Mo), coke formation, and exotherm induced uncontrollable condensation [138]. Therefore, a treatment section is necessary before HDO reactions, and Mei et al. proposed a suspended-bed hydrogenation treatment unit to combine with the fixed-bed HDO technology ( Fig. 7a) [134]. The waste biolipids are first treated in this suspended-bed hydrogenation unit to achieve deoxygenation, denitrogenation, and de-heavy-metallization. The liquid intermediates are separated and subjected to the HDO process in the fix-bed hydrogenation unit. The collected products are sent to a fractionation unit to get biogas, bio-naphtha, and biodiesel, separately. Thanks to the suspended-bed hydrogenation unit, the complex and energy consuming pre-treatment of raw biolipids can be eliminated. For the process of corn stover, the procedure is even more difficult including furfural preparation unit, levulinic acid preparation unit, condensation unit, HDO unit, and separation unit [135]. A simplified process flow diagram is displayed in Fig. 7b. The hemicellulose in corn stover is first degraded to furfural under acid conditions and extracted by saturated steam, followed by concentration to a furfural solution (10–16 wt%). The cellulose in residues can be further hydrolyzed under acid conditions to levulinic acid, followed by filtration, neutralization, and concentration to 1–2 wt% levulinic acid solution. The obtained furfural and levulinic acid undergo aldol condensation at basic conditions to form long-chain oxygenated compounds. The high-quality biofuels of C8∼C15 can be achieved after subsequent HDO and separation procedures. 6 Conclusions and outlook Biofuel is an important component of green energy and has become the focus and hotspot of scientific research. At this stage, due to immature production technology, its output is far from market demand. The key to vigor development lies in the design of high-performance and low-cost HDO catalysts. Due to the complexity and diversity of biomass raw materials, the reaction mechanism and structure-activity relationship should be thoroughly clarified, and production processes should be specifically designed for industrial applications. In this review, the design and synthesis of metal catalysts are discussed, which can be classified into five types: reducible metal oxides, metal sulfides, metal phosphides, metal carbides, and metal nitrides. The modification strategy for reducible noble metal oxides with the doping of an oxophilic metal can not only reduce the catalyst cost, but also improve the stability and activity via tuning the configuration of the adsorbed carbonyl groups. The in situ prepared metal sulfides during HDO reaction using oil-soluble precursors, such as ionic liquids with highly designable moieties, endows catalyst with high dispersion and low stacking properties towards efficient HDO performance. For the other three categories, appropriate design of catalyst active sites can achieve unexpected catalytic performance, such as (i) better activity towards HDO of phenolics for Ni3P2-terminated (Ni(2)) sites in comparison to Ni3P-terminated (Ni(1)) sites, (ii) more efficient activity towards HDO of anisole for orthorhombic β-Mo2C in comparison to α-W2C, and (iii) more significant activity towards HDO of methyl palmitate on NixMoCN, in comparison to MoCN with a β-Mo2C phase, via synergistic interaction of the C-O bonds activation on Mo2C and C-C bonds activation on Ni2Mo3N. In the design of metal active sites, suitable supports can also induce significant positive effects, such as (i) macro-structure of the support for the mitigation of metal aggregation and tunable accessibility of reagent fragments to metal sites, (ii) synergistic effect of metal-support interaction for better HDO performance, and (iii) surface acidity of support for controllable isomerization. Subsequently, the complex reaction mechanism for hydro-conversion of biomass to biofuels is reviewed with two typical feedstocks: methyl palmitate as the biolipids model compound and cellobiose as cellulose and hemicellulose model compound. Finally, the process for hydro-conversion of biomass is discussed with two typically examples to convert abundant waste biolipids and corn stover to biofuels via three major units: pre-treatment unit, HDO unit, and separation unit. Despite the progress in laboratory and industry, there are still challenges in the design, synthesis, and application of catalysts for large-scale production of biofuels from biomass: (i) The cleavage of C-O bonds and HDO of biolipids can be performed on various metal catalysts, such as Pt-, Ni-, and Mo-based catalysts. However, the C-C bond cleavage is difficult to control and the presence of DCO or DCO2 reduces carbon utilization and increases energy consumption, especially on bimetallic active sites and acidic supports. It is even more difficult to achieve simultaneous depolymerization and dehydrogenation during the conversion of lignocellulose to biofuels. Thus, proper design of metal catalysts with finely controllable active sites for high selectivity to HDO rather than to DCO or DCO2 is extremely preferred. (ii) At the present stage, HDO and isomerization are carried out separately with different catalysts, which consumes a large amount of hydrogen gas and increases operating costs. Using acidic support or modifying the acidity of support, some metal catalysts can have certain isomerization activity, but the acidity leads to coke formation and poor catalyst stability. Moreover, the low isomerization rate is far from meeting practical applications. Hence, there is an urgent need to develop more finely regulated catalysts taking advantage of synergistic effect, acidity, and morphology of support for one-step HDO and isomerization to convert biomass to low-freezing-point biofuels. (iii) The reaction mechanism for the conversion of biomass model compounds has been established. However, since the solid-liquid reaction of HDO is generally carried out under harsh conditions of high temperature and pressure, operando characterization and monitoring of active species are rarely reported. For lignocellulose raw materials, it is even more difficult due to the complexity of the reaction and the presence of solid residues. Hence, the operando approach will be the focus and challenges of future research. (iv) Fixed-bed is typically used in hydro-conversion of biomass to biofuels. The generation of fatty acid and water during reaction, coupled with the high temperature and pressure conditions, easily leads to pulverization and deactivation of catalyst bed. The “suspended bed” approach is an alternative to periodically replenish the deactivated catalysts with fresh ones. Furthermore, functional condensation units should be carefully considered to achieve high-density biofuels with long carbon chains and cyclic hydrocarbons. coredata.dc:description: As the effects of environmental problems and energy crises become apparent, zero carbon routes are vital to achieve large-scale production of fuels, such as efficient utilization of biomass to produce biofuels. This critical review provides a systematic summary and guidance on the catalytic conversion of waste biolipids and lignocellulose into biofuels via hydro-conversion in respect of metal catalysts and reaction mechanisms. First, five typical metal catalysts are reviewed, including reducible metal oxides, metal sulfides, metal phosphides, metal carbides, and metal nitrides. Among them, reducible metal oxides and metal sulfides are widely reported due to their efficient hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) activity. The design and preparation of catalysts from noble and non-noble metals, especially the rational design of catalyst active sites, are explored. For metal sulfides, novel in situ synthesis methods are summarized, especially in HDO reactions using oil-soluble precursors, such as ionic liquids with highly designable moieties. The importance of support is then discussed, particularly the positive effects of morphology, synergistic metal-support interactions, and surface acidity on HDO performance. Subsequently, the reaction mechanism of biomass hydrogenation treatment to produce biofuels was explored in detail using methyl palmitate as a biolipid model compound and cellobiose as cellulose and hemicellulose model compound. We also introduce two typical processes for hydro-conversion of biomass to biofuels involving three general units: pre-treatment unit, HDO unit, and separation unit. Finally, this review provides a summary and insights into catalyst design, one-pot isomerization, operando characterization, and reaction process development.
